prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story: My observation is there exists unequal share of State monies with its residents, before all the Urban residents get defensive please hear me out. Presently no one except Corporations pay State income taxes. No individual pays state taxes. I noticed state funded bicycle paths, road maintenance, defunct Docks, powerful politicians pet projects such as office buildings, state troopers etc, etc. all these fundings and more are not necessary within City limits, I was amazed at how much our state provides city functions in the bigger cities thus growing the state budget, I saw on tv last night how adg&g was showing the little ones how to ice fish, couldn't the parents do that? yes I pay property taxes. But I will guarantee you once our City folk get the full bill with out the State monies we will not be as wasteful, on the office building...rent what space you need and help the office rental marked. In my business I just retired from,I would ask my managers, "how do you stop spending money"?
stories:
Here's my rephrased text:

I've noticed that the distribution of state funds among residents is uneven, and I'd like to explain my point before urban residents react. Currently, corporations are the only ones paying state income taxes, not individuals. I've observed that state funding goes towards various projects, such as bike paths, road maintenance, abandoned docks, politicians' pet projects like office buildings, and state troopers, among others. These expenditures, while not essential within city limits, contribute to the growth of the state budget. I was struck by the extent to which the state provides funding for city functions in larger cities. Even initiatives like teaching children how to ice fish, which I saw on TV, could be handled by parents themselves. While I do pay property taxes, I'm convinced that if cities were to cover their own expenses without state funding, we would be more frugal. For instance, instead of building new office spaces, we could rent what's needed and support the office rental market. In my previous business, I would often ask my managers how they could curb unnecessary spending.

The allocation of state funds among residents appears to be lopsided, and I'd like to make my case before urban residents respond. Presently, state income taxes are borne solely by corporations, not individuals. I've taken note that state funding is directed towards a range of projects, including bike paths, road maintenance, abandoned docks, politicians' pet projects like office buildings, and state troopers, among others. Although these expenditures are not crucial within city limits, they contribute to the expansion of the state budget. I was surprised to find that the state provides significant funding for city functions in larger cities. Even initiatives like teaching children ice fishing, which I saw on TV, could be undertaken by parents themselves. As a property taxpayer, I'm convinced that if cities were to self-fund their expenses, we would be more financially prudent. For example, instead of constructing new office spaces, we could rent what's needed and support the office rental market. In my previous business, I would often ask my managers to identify ways to reduce unnecessary spending.

In my previous business, I would often ask my managers to identify ways to cut unnecessary spending.

The current tax system appears to prioritize large corporations over individual taxpayers, diverting funds towards initiatives driven by political agendas, such as infrastructure projects, which may not be vital in urban areas, thereby contributing to the growing state budget deficit. I was astonished to discover that the state allocates substantial funding for municipal services in larger cities. Certain initiatives, like teaching children ice fishing, could be undertaken by parents themselves. As a taxpayer and property owner, I think granting cities greater autonomy over their finances would result in more prudent spending. For instance, instead of constructing new offices, we could rent the necessary spaces and stimulate the office rental market. In my previous business, I always instructed my managers to identify and eliminate unnecessary expenditures.
